ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my understanding of both philosophy and more specifically Indian Philosophy, and I believe I improved my ability to establish a philosophical argument as well.
Basic knowledge of different doctrines and belief systems in Indian philosophy.
This course vastly improved my understanding of eastern philosophy. I learned quite a bit, it was a treat!
I developed the knowledge, skills, and insights to incorporate Indian philosophy into my every day practices of living, specifically dealing with suffering.
-intro to early indian philiosphy
I gained a greater knowledge and even deeper appreciation for Indian Philosophy, specifically Brahminical philosophy.
I gained a basic understanding of the origins, progression, and development of Indian philosophy.
I did learn a lot about Indian Philosophy.
Engaging in philosophical thought
I gained an understanding of Indian philosophy, and the practice of philosophy more generally, that I did not have at all before.
I learned about different facets of indian philosophy
broad survey of Indian Philosophy

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course readings tended to be very loosely required, which made them easy to disengage from and in turn made the lectures more boring. Additionally, more space for questions (which would likely be facilitated simply by moving the course in person) would also help.

Strengths: the material was very interesting, Professor Uskokov is very knowledgeable and interested in hearing from students, and the lecture notes and slides are detailed and helpful. Weaknesses: the course moved quickly through a wide breadth of doctrines, and it was sometimes difficult to trace different themes and similar belief systems through the course.
-passionate teacher
I thought the lectures could be dry but its hard to make philosophy lectures too riveting in the first place.

The strengths of this class were that it was quite flexible. I found that I was able to come to class prepared with the readings each day. The readings were also incredibly interesting. The one thing that was difficult was that, as someone who hasn't spent much time studying philosophy before this class, there was a bit of a learning curve for me.
I think that this course was pretty in depth, and I wish I knew more about Indian Philosophy going into the class.

Not enough of an introduction to philosophy for those who were unfamiliar. Also, the quiz study guide would have been more helpful if given before the readings so that we knew what to focus on in the readings.
professor was confusing and material is extremely hard and complex to grasp on its own
The subject matter was interesting but I fo wish we could have had more discussion.

This was an interesting course that spent a lot of time on the details of various schools of ancient Indian philosophical thought. This was both a strength and a weakness--it was a strength in the sense that this is where many fruitful discussions lie and where the schools of thought are at their most interesting. However, this may also be a weakness for some students, because the arguments we learned about were at times very niche/theoretical and may have been hard to follow. 

One suggestion I have is to maybe re-shuffle the order of lecture. At times it felt like we were diving right in to a highly complicated subject, but grouping lectures by type (eg epistemology, philosophy of mind, etc.) and giving a broad overview of the positions of different schools/of the terminology they use may have helped lecture be more accessible.
This class is good for students that are very interested in the material.
the quizzes effective assessments and a good way to digest the material. lectures were a bit disorganized and I wished there was more discussion on the central philosophical problems

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: -none
N/A
I think the course was okay. It was hard with Covid because there was not a lot of interaction between the teacher and the students.

The reading assignments were far too much. Sufficient discussion could have been facilitated with fewer amount of pages read. I appreciated the participation points for reading the assignments though.
An online lecture is difficult, but it was fairly easy to not engage with the class.
Recording the lectures in addition to them being live was great for flexibility during the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this course was accessible to students with a background in philosophy and those without one.

Yes! The material was fascinating and well presented. Professor Uskokov is a talented lecturer and an impressive authority on the subject matter. It was a great course online, I can only imagine how good it will be in person.
If that's what you are interested in. If not, it would just go over your head.
-yes if interested in early Indian philosophy
Absolutely! Its fascinating and really fulfilling.

I would, it is an accessible entry point into the world of Eastern philosophy. A good class to add if one is interested in taking a philosophy class that will be both informative/enjoyable and relaxed.
I would but only to a humanity student. While I think that it was interesting, there was a lot of vocabulary thrown at us and a lot of terms that confused me.
Yes, highly. The professor was very knowledgeable and always willing to help, explain, or debate.
Yes, it gave a diverse survey of Indian philosophy in multiple areas.
not really unless you are truly interested in indian philosophy and perhaps have a brief background in it
If someone is interested in taking a class with relatively light committment and wanting to explore really interesting ideas, I would recommend the class.
Yes if this is a topic you are interested in/if you are generally interested in philosophy.
I would recommend this course to students that are interested in the material.
it's something new

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

-none
N/A
There were only virtual lectures in this course.
